awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) award to Northern Arizona University will implement and test a new consortium model for building a multi-institution, multi-disciplinary, high-quality graduate curricula. This collaborative effort ? WindU, for graduate training in wind energy - between Northern Arizona University, Texas Tech University, Penn State University, and the University of Massachusetts Amherst will offer expanded graduate educational opportunities beyond what each institution can provide. The project team will pilot and test a new, replicable model for creating an expandable consortium in STEM graduate education, designed to increase the breadth and frequency of course offerings and educational opportunities available to a diverse group of students. The new model, Rapid, proposes an innovative delineation of the elements required to successfully set up a consortium, covering a range of activities from curriculum planning to financial agreements, consortium management and governance, student support systems and course delivery, and including future consortium expansion and sustainability. Also innovative is its goal to create a consortium that is readily able to add new members, and the inclusion of webinars shared among consortium members and international partner organizations for swift diffusion of new knowledge. As universities respond to society's demand for educational programs in rapidly evolving technical fields, models for multi-university, multi-disciplinary consortiums such as Rapid provide critical pathways for success. 

The main objective of the project is to pilot and test the Rapid model, and to add to the knowledge base in how to effectively establish a consortium. The Rapid model is a new facilitation model developed from evidence-based models described in the literature and implemented in practice. The goal of the project is to study the pilot-test of the Rapid model as applied to a consortium in wind energy graduate education (WindU). Questions guiding this research study are: 1) How was the Rapid model used for developing a consortium in STEM graduate education? and, 2) In what ways was the Rapid model effective for consortium development? The project team will use a design and development research process described in the Common Guidelines for Education Research and Development to provide real-time evidence for model pilot-testing during consortium development and, ultimately, for identifying the final model for dissemination. Design-based research supports the development and continuous improvement of education innovations in complex systems, such as the WindU consortium, by engaging the program team in iterative cycles of design, implementation, analysis and redesign.

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

IGE: WindU - A Multi-University Consortium in Wind Energy Graduate Education - Meeting a National Need

WindU was a collaborative effort between Northern Arizona University, Texas Tech University, Penn State University, and the University of Massachusetts Amherst to jointly plan and offer expanded graduate educational opportunities in wind energy. Building upon published literature, the project team piloted and tested a new, replicable model for rapidly creating an expandable, multi-university, multi-disciplinary consortium in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) graduate education, designed to increase the breadth and frequency of course offerings and educational opportunities available to a diverse group of students. The new model, Rapid, describes a comprehensive set of activities to successfully set up a consortium in one year, including curriculum planning, financial agreements, consortium management and governance, student support systems and course delivery, and consortium sustainability. Wind energy graduate education is the STEM discipline in which the model was tested.

The purpose in creating a multi-university consortium is to leverage the academic talent and programs of several universities together in a common vision to create a robust STEM graduate academic program, available online, with the breadth of courses required to meet the needs of students, business, research, and society. STEM education is rapidly evolving as technology evolves and as educational practices and tools advance. For example, since the turn of the century in 2000, wind energy transformed from a nascent technology with potential into what is now one of the lowest cost forms of electric power generation available. As a technology, the engineering and development of wind systems spans the topics of atmospheric science, environmental science and policy, mechanical and materials engineering, design, fluid mechanics, electrical engineering, control systems, civil engineering, power systems, social sciences, optimization, computing, economics, and more. For any single university, it would be difficult to have expertise in all these fields, let alone faculty with experience in applying that expertise in any one specialization such as wind energy. Similarly, since 2000, the ability to deliver high-quality university programs has expanded from primarily in-person, on-campus classes to online programs available both synchronously and asynchronously. Successful, effective, online educational consortiums that rely on multiple universities are now more possible than ever.

The Rapid model tested a suite of coordinated activities involving defined teams of university staff and faculty both within and across universities to set up a consortium of graduate education courses. Several "functional teams" were convened to address planning activities including courses and curriculum, financial agreements, consortium management and governance, student support systems and course delivery, and future consortium expansion and sustainability. The model was successfully applied, and the "WindU" consortium was created and sharing courses within a year. The financial model required sharing $500 per semester credit hour (an amount less than the lowest per-credit-hour cost at any of the partner universities), with this amount being split 70% to the teaching institution, 20% for management of the consortium, and 10% remaining with the home institution of each student to support its participation in the consortium. After establishment, the consortium shared nine courses over the final two-years of the grant, with 92 students participating. Data was collected on the effectiveness of the model via interviews with a broad group of participants responsible for setting-up and implementing the consortium. The interviews supported several aspects of the model, in particular its use of functional teams and the need for campus champions and an objective facilitator, but also highlighted deficiencies related to the need for more communication, course approval and instructor qualifications at each university, and full involvement of the university programs with financial obligations. Challenges uncovered in setting-up the financial model included how to handle students with tuition waivers (e.g., teaching assistants), how to ensure graduate students at the universities were eligible for the courses offered at the partner universities, and ensuring the programs responsible for sending tuition to the partner institutions were aware of the costs and benefits. The experience of the project team in piloting the model combined with the interviews led to several revisions of the Rapid model, depicted in the illustration below. The intellectual merit of the project centered on the creation of the Rapid model, its investigation and revision, and dissemination of the results at national conferences such as the North American Wind Energy Academy (NAWEA) WindTech Conference, and other venues. The broader impacts include establishment of the consortium, publicly available webinars from international experts, and wind energy programs made available to online students broadening the potential to reach a diversity of communities.
